intro: Eminia holubii, commonly known as the Armenian bellflower, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the mountainous regions of the Caucasus. It typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and features lance-shaped leaves with a slightly hairy surface. The plant produces showy blue to violet flowers that bloom in late summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. It thrives in well-drained soils and prefers full sun to partial shade. Eminia holubii is often found in rocky or alpine habitats, showcasing its adaptability to harsh environments.
